raw_text:
Bryan twins keep US hopes alive
 
 The United States kept the Davis Cup final alive with victory in Saturday's doubles rubber, leaving Spain 2-1 ahead going into the final day.
 
 Masters Cup champions Mike and Bob Bryan thrashed Juan Carlos Ferrero and Tommy Robredo 6-0 6-3 6-2 in front of a partisan crowd in Seville. Victory would have given Spain the title but they were outclassed. In Sunday's reverse singles, Carlos Moya takes on Andy Roddick before Rafael Nadal faces Mardy Fish. "It feels good, but it's not going to be as good if we don't win two tomorrow," said Mike Bryan. "It feels good to give those guys another shot, and Spain has to go to sleep on that." Bob Bryan added: "I'm really confident in Andy winning that first match, and then anything can happen." Spain coach Jordi Arrese chose to rest 18-year-old Nadal in the doubles after his epic singles win over Roddick on Friday. He was replaced by former world number one Ferrero, but the Spanish pair were out of their depth against one of the world's best doubles teams.
 
 The 26-year-old Bryan twins have won all four of their Davis Cup matches this year. And they quickly silenced the huge crowd at the Olympic Stadium, racing through the opening set to love. The Spaniards then twice surrendered breaks of serve at the start of the second before the Bryans broke to go 5-3 ahead and served out. When Robredo dropped serve in the opening game of the third set the match was all but over, and the unflappable Bryan brothers powered on to an impressive win. Ferrero, who was upset to be dropped for Friday's singles, hinted at further dissatisfaction after the defeat. "It was a difficult game against the best doubles players," he said. "They have everything calculated and we had very little to do. "I was a bit surprised that I was named to play the doubles match because I hardly play doubles." Arrese said: "Juan Carlos hasn't played at all badly. He played the right way but the Bryans are great doubles players."
llama3.2:1b: The United States secured a 2-1 victory in the Davis Cup final over Spain, thanks to wins by Mike and Bob Bryan in the doubles rubber and Andy Roddick's loss in the reverse singles match. The US took advantage of Spain's resting star player Rafael Nadal in the doubles, who was replaced by Juan Carlos Ferrero due to their lack of experience against the world's top doubles team.
llama3.2:3b: US twins Bryan win doubles, keep Davis Cup hopes alive, 2-1 down going into final day; Ferrero and Robredo thrashed in doubles, Nadal rested for Sunday's singles.
gemma2:2b:
The Bryan twins defeated Spain in the Davis Cup doubles, giving the US a chance to win. 
Spain's hopes of winning the title were thwarted by the Americans' dominance.  They now face reverse singles on Sunday, with Andy Roddick and Rafael Nadal facing their Spanish counterparts.
qwen2.5:0.5b: The United States Davis Cup team won their fourth straight match, sending Spain 2-1 ahead after a tight match in Seville on Saturday. Spain's Mike and Bob Bryan dominated the doubles match with Juan Carlos Ferrero and Tommy Robredo beating them 6-0 6-3 6-2. The Spanish players were up against another great player, Juan Mari Moya, who will face Andy Roddick in the singles final. The Spaniards also defeated Ricki Ferraro (from Spain) after losing to Tommy Robedo (USA). "It feels good for us to have a chance of winning," said Mike Bryan, while his brother Bob Bryan expressed confidence in Andy Rodman's performance.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Bryan twins won Davis Cup final doubles rubber, 2-1 against Spain.
qwen2.5:3b: The United States kept their Davis Cup final alive with victory in Saturday's doubles rubber, leaving Spain 2-1 ahead heading into the final day. Mike and Bob Bryan defeated Juan Carlos Ferrero and Tommy Robredo 6-0, 6-3, 6-2, securing a crucial win for the US. The loss was particularly harsh for Spain as they were without top player Rafa Nadal due to injury. Spain will face Andy Roddick in Sunday's singles matches. Despite their impressive victory, Mike Bryan acknowledged that winning both remaining matches would be necessary for the United States to clinch the title. Ferrero expressed disappointment with his selection for the doubles match and admitted they were outclassed by one of the world's best doubles teams.

The Spaniards then conceded twice breaks of serve in the opening game of the third set but the pair were unbeaten on both sets. They quickly surrendered and continued playing until Robredo's defeat led to more dissatisfaction from both players. Despite this, they were not disappointed when Ferrero hinted at further disappointment after the defeat.

Victory would have given Spain the title but they were outclassed. In Saturday's reverse singles, Carlos Moya took on Andy Roddick before Rafael Nadal faces Mardy Fish. "It feels good to give those guys another shot, and Spain has to go to sleep on that." Bob Bryan added: "I'm really confident in Andy winning that first match, and then anything can happen." Bob Bryan chose to rest 18-year-old Nadal in the doubles after his epic singles win over Roddick on Friday. He was replaced by former world number one Ferrero, but the Spanish pair were out of their depth against one of the world's best doubles teams.

Bryan Twins Keep US hopes alive: In a thrilling match at the Davis Cup finals, Bryan twins Mike and Bob Bryan kept the momentum going with a victory in Saturday's doubles rubber, securing a 2-1 lead against Spain. They earned the title through an impressive performance, with Mike Bryan highlighting that while the victory was significant, it wasn't as good if they don't win two more games tomorrow. Bob Bryan added his confidence, saying Andy Roddick would make them another shot. Meanwhile, their coach Jordi Arrese rested Juan Carlos Ferrero for the opposing team's doubles match, but he replaced him with Tommy Robredo and gave his former partner Rafael Nadal a chance to shine. The match was close in the third set when Tom rodo dropped the serve early, leaving the Spaniards up 5-3. The brothers' strategy had paid off, as they bounced back to win 6-2-1 over Carlos Moya and Andy Roddick. Their victory would have been enough for Spain, but Ferrero was upset after missing Friday's doubles match.
tinyllama:1.1b: The Davis Cup Final between the United States and Spain has been a nail-biter, with both teams coming out victorious in the doubles rubber. The Bryan twins have made a strong case for retaining their Davis Cup title, winning all four of their matches this year. However, the Spanish pair were outclassed by the Bryans, who thrashed Juan Carlos Ferrero and Tommy Robredo 6-0 and 6-3 respectively in the reverse singles. The Bryan Brothers now look to win both their remaining matches in the final day, including their match against Rafael Nadal, who was rested after his epic singles victory over Andy Roddick on Friday. Despite the loss, Spain coach Jordi Arrese chose to rest Ferrero for the doubles, indicating that he sees no need for another resting spot for the elite doubles pair.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The Davis Cup has been a critical event for the United States, keeping it in the running for the World Group finals. In their first round-robin match against Spain, the Bryan brothers defeated Juan Carlos Ferrero and Tommy Robredo, giving the US the momentum needed to win the tournament. However, Spain managed to fight back, winning the following two rubbers before they could capitalize on their advantage. Meanwhile, the Bryans faced another challenge in resting 18-year-old Rafael Nadal for the first match of the singles. Despite facing a tough opponent in Andy Roddick, the Spanish team was unable to keep up with the twins' dominance and had to resort to resting their best doubles player, Carlos Moya. The Bryan brothers continued to prove their worth on the big stage, proving that they are ready to give it their all against the world's best doubles teams.
phi:2.7b: The United States won in Saturday's doubles rubber against Spain, leading 2-1 going into the final day of the Davis Cup Final. Masters Cup champions Mike and Bob Bryan thrashed their opponents 6-0, 6-3, and 6-2 in front of a partisan crowd at Seville's Olympic Stadium. However, Spain was outclassed by the Bryan brothers in Sunday's doubles match and had to rely on their opponent's defeat in the singles tournament to secure the title.
